text: the poorest country in the Western
Hemisphere denuded devastated by another
natural disaster initial reports were of
flooding and destruction Brown torrents
of water that had washed homes and
villages from the landscape but only now
three days after Matthew are we getting
a clearer picture of what the aid
agencies are facing from initial
estimates of five dead the count is now
300 and rising a lot of rain and and we
continue to intensified and by between
six and seven thirty it was the worse
then we thought it was over and
everybody came out then they spent about
an hour then he started over again it
was the worst part the eye of the storm
crossed to the southernmost tip of the
peninsula and through the city of Jeremy
a million people are affected there are
reports at least 80% of the homes are
destroyed they predict more bodies will
appear as the waters recede the UN says
the biggest challenge will be restoring
clean water and sanitation Haiti was
already in the grip of a cholera
epidemic which has killed over 10,000
people since 2010 and in this
environment with sewage canals inundated
disease will spread and with bridges
damaged and many roads still impassable
the relief effort has been badly
hampered the Red Cross say they're
caring for some 38,000 people in
shelters with more arriving this aid
worker says they don't have enough water
we can't help the people he said there's
no food the US Navy is responding
they've deployed nine helicopters to
lift supplies but with Matthew still
barreling north now taunting the eastern
seaboard of the United States
the danger is Haiti will be overlooked
at a time when the need is most acute
Christian Fraser BBC News
